title: 108_hr482
content:
The "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture and "State" as the State of Florida. It also addresses the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. These tracts include approximately 40 acres in East Bay, Santa Rosa County, 0.59 acres in Ft. Walton, Okaloosa County, 79.90 acres southeast of Crestview, Okaloosa County, 30.14 acres at the Okaloosa County Fairgrounds, and a City Ball Park tract in Ft. Walton, Okaloosa County. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. These tracts include approximately 40 acres in East Bay, Santa Rosa County, 0.59 acres in Ft. Walton, Okaloosa County, 79.90 acres southeast of Crestview, Okaloosa County, 30.14 acres at the Okaloosa County Fairgrounds, a City Ball Park tract in Ft. Walton, Okaloosa County, and other various parcels in Liberty County. Located southeast of Crestview, Okaloosa County, consisting of approximately 40.85 acres, tract A-959 in Bristol, Liberty County, consisting of approximately 0.5 acres, tract C-3m-d in Lake County, consisting of approximately 15.0 acres, tract C-691 in Lake County, consisting of subsurface rights to approximately 40.76 acres of land, and tract C-2208b in Lake County, consisting of approximately 39.99 acres. Tracts C-691, C-2208b, C-2209, C-2209b, and C-2209c in Lake County consist of various acreages and are described by their respective sections and quarters. Tracts C-2209b, C-2209c, and C-2209d in Lake County consist of approximately 39.41 acres, 40.09 acres, and 79.58 acres respectively. Tract C-2210 in Marion County includes 20 recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr, totaling approximately 30 acres. Tract C-2213 in Marion County is located in the F.M. Arrendondo grant East of Ocala. (16) Tract C-2210 in Marion County includes 20 recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr, totaling approximately 30 acres. 
(17) Tract C-2213 in Marion County, located in the F.M. Arrendondo grant East of Ocala, consists of approximately 15.0 acres. 
(18) All improvements on the parcels described in paragraphs (1) through (17) can be modified for sale or exchange based on a survey. The Secretary may modify land descriptions for soliciting offers for sale or exchange based on a survey or public interest. Offers for land described in subsection (b) can be solicited, and inadequate offers may be rejected. The Secretary may solicit offers for the sale or exchange of land described in subsection (b) and reject offers that are inadequate or not in the public interest. The land can be sold at public or private sale, and real estate brokers can be used with a comparable commission to those in the area. The Secretary may use real estate brokers to facilitate the sale or exchange of land, paying them a commission comparable to local rates. The Secretary of the Air Force must approve the sale or exchange of certain parcels of land. In cases where the value of non-Federal land is less than Federal land exchanged, a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% may be accepted. The Secretary of the Air Force may accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% if the value of non-Federal land is less than the Federal land exchanged. Net proceeds from any sale or exchange will be deposited in the fund established by the Sisk Act for land acquisition without further appropriation. The Sisk Act (Public Law 90-171) allows the Secretary to use deposited funds for land acquisition and reimbursement of costs related to land sales and exchanges without further appropriation. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION.

Land acquired by the United States under this Act shall be subject to the Weeks Act and administered in accordance with laws applicable to the National Forest System. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from location, entry, and patent under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws.
